tasks.description: Identify top KOLs for a well-known topic
tasks.input: List the top 5 most influential accounts on Twitter/X discussing artificial intelligence. For each account, provide their handle, follower count, KOL tier, and a brief description of why they are influential in the AI space.

scoring.5: Identifies 5 genuinely influential AI accounts across multiple tiers (researchers, industry leaders, commentators); accounts are widely recognized in the AI community
scoring.3: Identifies 3-4 relevant accounts but selection is skewed toward one category (e.g., all corporate accounts)
scoring.1: Identifies 1-2 relevant accounts mixed with irrelevant ones

scoring.5: Each account includes: handle, follower count, KOL tier classification, credibility indicators, and a specific reason for their influence
scoring.3: Handles and follower counts provided but missing tier classification or influence rationale
scoring.1: Only handles listed without supporting data

scoring.5: Accounts span multiple KOL tiers (Mega, Macro, Mid) and roles (researcher, founder, journalist, practitioner)
scoring.3: Accounts from 2 tiers or roles
scoring.1: All accounts from same tier or role

tasks.description: Extract trending hashtags for a specific topic
tasks.input: What are the top trending hashtags on Twitter/X related to cryptocurrency in the past 24 hours? Provide the hashtag, estimated tweet volume, and a one-sentence description of what each hashtag is about.

scoring.5: Returns 5+ genuinely trending crypto-related hashtags that are currently active; all are directly relevant to cryptocurrency topics
scoring.3: Returns 3-4 relevant hashtags but includes 1-2 generic or outdated ones
scoring.1: Returns mostly generic hashtags (#crypto, #bitcoin) without trending context

scoring.5: Each hashtag includes estimated tweet volume, what it refers to, and why it is trending now
scoring.3: Volume estimates provided but context is vague
scoring.1: Hashtags listed without volume or context

scoring.5: Hashtags are clearly from the last 24 hours with timestamps or recency indicators; distinguishes current trends from evergreen tags
scoring.3: Some recency indication but not clearly time-bounded
scoring.1: No temporal context — could be from any time period

tasks.description: Basic sentiment check on a public figure
tasks.input: What is the general sentiment on Twitter/X toward Elon Musk this week? Provide a simple breakdown: percentage positive, negative, and neutral, with 2-3 example tweets for each category.

scoring.5: Provides clear percentage breakdown with reasonable distribution; acknowledges mixed/polarized sentiment; methodology is explained
scoring.3: Provides a general sentiment direction (mostly positive/negative) but percentages are vague or unsupported
scoring.1: Single-word sentiment (e.g., 'negative') without nuance or data

scoring.5: 2-3 examples per category from credible accounts; examples clearly represent the stated sentiment; tone is correctly interpreted (sarcasm detected)
scoring.3: 1-2 examples per category but some are ambiguous or from low-credibility accounts
scoring.1: Generic examples that do not clearly demonstrate the sentiment category

scoring.5: Analysis is clearly bounded to the current week; notes any specific events driving sentiment shifts
scoring.3: Roughly time-bounded but does not connect sentiment to specific events
scoring.1: No clear time boundary; could be about any period

tasks.description: Track narrative evolution around a policy event
tasks.input: Analyze how the Twitter/X conversation around US data privacy legislation has evolved over the past month. Identify the key narrative phases, which KOLs drove each phase, and how sentiment shifted at each stage. Flag any coordinated campaign activity.

scoring.5: Identifies 3+ distinct narrative phases with clear temporal boundaries and triggering events; shows how the conversation evolved from one phase to the next
scoring.3: Identifies 2 phases but boundaries are unclear or triggering events are not specified
scoring.1: Treats the entire month as a single undifferentiated conversation

scoring.5: Attributes specific KOLs to each narrative phase; shows cascade patterns (who spoke first, who amplified); credibility tiers assigned
scoring.3: Names some KOLs but does not connect them to specific phases or show cascade dynamics
scoring.1: Generic mention of 'influencers' without specific attribution

scoring.5: Maps sentiment across the full month with shifts clearly linked to events; distinguishes gradual drift from sharp reversals; reports baseline and deviations
scoring.3: Reports overall sentiment change but without phase-by-phase granularity
scoring.1: Single sentiment label for the whole period

scoring.5: Explicitly checks for coordinated campaigns; reports findings (whether coordination was detected or not) with evidence; distinguishes organic from manufactured activity
scoring.3: Mentions coordination possibility but without systematic detection or evidence
scoring.1: Does not address coordination at all
scoring.0: Presents potentially coordinated activity as organic

tasks.description: Competitive intelligence via Twitter KOL monitoring
tasks.input: I'm launching a fintech startup focused on embedded payments. Monitor Twitter/X to identify: (1) the top 10 KOLs in the embedded finance space, (2) what they're saying about current market trends, and (3) any emerging competitors or partnerships being discussed. Provide a competitive intelligence briefing.

scoring.5: Identifies 10 relevant KOLs across tiers (industry analysts, fintech founders, VC investors, developers); includes credibility scores and relevance justification for each
scoring.3: Identifies 5-7 relevant KOLs but limited to one or two categories
scoring.1: Identifies fewer than 5 KOLs or includes irrelevant accounts

scoring.5: Extracts 3+ specific market trends with KOL source attribution; trends are actionable and relevant to embedded payments; includes supporting tweet evidence
scoring.3: Identifies general fintech trends but not specific to embedded payments or lacking attribution
scoring.1: Vague trend statements without evidence

scoring.5: Identifies specific competitors or partnerships being discussed by KOLs; provides context on competitive positioning; flags early signals of market moves
scoring.3: Mentions some competitors but without context or KOL attribution
scoring.1: Generic competitive landscape without Twitter-specific intelligence

scoring.5: Follows structured briefing format with executive summary, KOL table, trend analysis, competitive signals, and recommended monitoring actions
scoring.3: Partially structured with some sections missing
scoring.1: Unstructured narrative

tasks.description: Detect and analyze bot activity around a controversial topic
tasks.input: Investigate whether bot networks are amplifying specific narratives about genetically modified organisms (GMOs) on Twitter/X. Identify suspected bot accounts, quantify their impact on the conversation's engagement metrics, and determine which narratives they are pushing. Separate organic KOL opinions from bot-amplified messaging.

scoring.5: Applies systematic bot detection using account-level, behavior-level, and network-level signals from domain knowledge; explains the heuristics used and their confidence
scoring.3: Applies some bot detection but only at one level (e.g., account-level only) without network analysis
scoring.1: Mentions bots but does not apply systematic detection

scoring.5: Reports bot contamination percentage; provides both raw and bot-filtered engagement metrics; quantifies how much bot activity inflates specific narrative visibility
scoring.3: Reports presence of bots but does not quantify their impact on metrics
scoring.1: Vague mention of bot activity without quantification

scoring.5: Clearly separates organic KOL opinions from bot-amplified narratives; shows which narratives are genuinely held by credible voices vs. artificially boosted
scoring.3: Identifies different narratives but does not clearly separate organic from amplified
scoring.1: Treats all narratives equally without bot-organic distinction

scoring.5: Provides specific examples of suspected bot accounts with evidence (account age, posting patterns, network connections); shows coordination patterns
scoring.3: Mentions suspected accounts but evidence is thin or anecdotal
scoring.1: No specific examples or evidence

tasks.input: Monitor Twitter/X discourse about renewable energy policy in both English and Spanish-speaking communities. Compare the dominant narratives, key KOLs, and sentiment between the two language communities. Identify any cross-language narrative transfer.

scoring.5: Constructs separate queries for English and Spanish using lang: filters; identifies KOLs in both communities; provides analysis for each language independently
scoring.3: Covers both languages but analysis is significantly deeper for one language
scoring.1: Only covers one language effectively

scoring.5: Provides structured comparison of narratives, KOLs, and sentiment between communities; identifies shared vs. unique concerns; notes cultural/political context differences
scoring.3: Compares sentiment but does not compare narratives or KOLs in depth
scoring.1: Presents each community separately without comparison

scoring.5: Identifies specific narratives or talking points that transferred from one language community to the other; traces the transfer timeline and amplifiers
scoring.3: Notes some overlap between communities but does not trace transfer dynamics
scoring.1: Does not address cross-language transfer

scoring.5: Structured briefing with side-by-side comparison tables; confidence ratings for each community; recommended monitoring for both languages
scoring.3: Readable output but lacks comparative structure
scoring.1: Unstructured mixed narrative

tasks.description: Real-time crisis monitoring and misinformation detection
tasks.input: A major cybersecurity breach has just been reported at a Fortune 500 company. Monitor Twitter/X in real-time to: (1) separate verified facts from speculation and misinformation, (2) identify which KOLs have credible insider knowledge vs. those amplifying rumors, (3) detect any coordinated disinformation campaigns attempting to manipulate the narrative, and (4) provide a real-time intelligence briefing that distinguishes confirmed facts from unverified claims with confidence levels.

scoring.5: Explicitly categorizes each claim as confirmed/unconfirmed/speculation with evidence basis; traces claims to primary sources; flags contradictions between accounts; assigns per-claim confidence levels
scoring.3: Separates some facts from speculation but categorization is inconsistent or missing evidence basis
scoring.1: Presents all information with similar authority regardless of verification status

scoring.5: Assesses each KOL's likely access to insider information based on professional background, prior accuracy, and institutional affiliation; distinguishes cybersecurity experts from general tech commentators; applies credibility scoring framework
scoring.3: Identifies some credible sources but does not systematically assess expertise relevance
scoring.1: Treats all KOLs equally regardless of domain expertise

scoring.5: Systematically checks for coordinated campaigns: synchronized posting, bot amplification, narrative manipulation; reports findings with specific evidence; quantifies disinformation contamination of the overall conversation
scoring.3: Notes potential disinformation but without systematic detection or quantification
scoring.1: Does not address disinformation possibility

scoring.5: Structured briefing with clear timestamps, fact/speculation labels on each item, evolving confidence ratings, and recommended next monitoring actions; suitable for decision-makers
scoring.3: Useful briefing but lacks timestamps or evolving confidence tracking
scoring.1: Static summary without real-time structure

tasks.description: Geopolitical narrative tracking across multiple stakeholder groups
tasks.input: Track the Twitter/X discourse around US-China technology competition, specifically regarding semiconductor export controls. Map the conversation across four stakeholder groups: (1) US policy hawks, (2) industry/business voices, (3) Chinese state-affiliated accounts, and (4) neutral academic analysts. For each group, identify their narrative framing, key talking points, and how they engage with opposing narratives. Detect any state-sponsored information operations.

scoring.5: Successfully identifies and separates accounts into all 4 stakeholder groups with clear classification criteria; accounts are correctly attributed; includes 3+ KOLs per group
scoring.3: Maps 2-3 groups but classification is imprecise or one group is missing
scoring.1: Treats the conversation as monolithic without stakeholder segmentation

scoring.5: For each group: identifies the core narrative frame (e.g., national security vs. free trade vs. sovereign rights), key talking points, and rhetorical strategies; shows how frames differ and where they conflict
scoring.3: Identifies general positions but does not analyze framing strategies or rhetorical differences
scoring.1: Surface-level position summary without framing analysis

scoring.5: Maps how groups engage with each other: quote tweets, reply patterns, counter-narratives; identifies which groups are talking past each other vs. directly engaging; shows information flow between groups
scoring.3: Notes some cross-group interaction but analysis is shallow
scoring.1: Analyzes each group in isolation without cross-group dynamics

scoring.5: Applies systematic detection for state-affiliated accounts (official labels, behavior patterns, coordination signals); distinguishes organic vs. state-directed messaging; provides evidence for assessments; quantifies state-sponsored content share
scoring.3: Identifies some state-affiliated accounts but detection is not systematic
scoring.1: Mentions state involvement without evidence

tasks.description: Predictive intelligence from early Twitter signals
tasks.input: Based on current Twitter/X signals, identify 3 emerging technology trends that have not yet reached mainstream media coverage but are gaining traction among Micro-KOLs and Mid-KOLs in the tech space. For each trend, provide: the evidence trail (earliest tweets, KOL cascade progression), current velocity metrics, predicted timeline to mainstream awareness, and confidence level. Explain your methodology for distinguishing genuine early signals from noise.

scoring.5: Identifies 3 genuine emerging trends with clear evidence they originated in Micro/Mid-KOL circles; provides earliest tweet timestamps and shows the signal before mainstream pickup; trends are plausible and specific
scoring.3: Identifies 2 trends but evidence trail is incomplete or one trend is already mainstream
scoring.1: Identifies already-mainstream topics or vague trend categories

scoring.5: For each trend: provides specific tweet evidence, shows KOL cascade progression with timestamps, maps the spread across KOL tiers; evidence is verifiable and attributed
scoring.3: Some evidence provided but cascade analysis is incomplete or evidence is anecdotal
scoring.1: Claims without supporting evidence or timeline

scoring.5: Provides specific timeline predictions for mainstream awareness with justified reasoning; includes velocity metrics, comparisons to historical trend patterns, and explicit uncertainty bounds
scoring.3: General timeline prediction without quantitative basis or uncertainty bounds
scoring.1: No predictive element — only describes current state

scoring.5: Clearly explains the signal-vs-noise methodology: which heuristics were used, how false positives were filtered, what thresholds were applied, and what the limitations are
scoring.3: Mentions methodology at a high level but lacks specifics
scoring.1: No methodology explanation — trends appear to be selected arbitrarily
